question: Do S. cerevisiae cells lacking RNA surveillance components (e.g., Rnt1p, Rrp6p, Xrn1p, or Rat1p) exhibit hypersensitivity to high-iron conditions? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: RNase III-deficient cells are hypersensitive to high iron concentrations, suggesting that Rnt1p-mediated RNA surveillance is required to prevent iron toxicity.
content.source_2: Under iron-replete conditions, deletion of RNT1 or the nuclear exosome component RRP6 failed to derepress iron uptake and mobilization mRNAs, and Δrnt1 and Δrrp6 strains maintained wild-type growth in 3–5 mM FeSO4, indicating that RNA surveillance is not required to protect against high-iron stress.
content.source_3: These results show that RNA surveillance through multiple ribonucleolytic pathways plays a role in iron homeostasis in yeast to avoid the potentially toxic effects of the expression of the iron starvation response in iron-replete conditions.
content.source_4: Contrary to models of RNA quality control, extended iron transport transcripts did not accumulate in rnt1Δ, xrn1Δ, or rat1-1 mutants, and loss of these 5′→3′ decay activities was associated with enhanced tolerance to ferric ammonium citrate in liquid culture assays, arguing that RNA surveillance does not mediate iron sensitivity.
